Bruce - two very big claims with nothing to support it. Boy will you be proven wrong, as JB like to quote, "in the sort-term the stock market is a voting machine, in the long-term it is a weighing machine". Right now, JB and AMZN are popular and winning votes, but there is no "weight" to the company. No cash flow (and almost out of cash), and no earnings with shrinking growth = zero weight. They haven't accompished anything but grow revenue at a loss - something almost anyone can do. As for the best living CEO's, I'll take Jack Welch over JB by a long shot .. For current CEO's Jamie Dimon, Warren Buffet, Dave Cote, or Larry Page any day over JB.

Topic.Title: When an rsi taps 80 the stok scam iz to let it melt up for a while

Message.Msg: Sybs is the most vocal and by far the most entertaining. But, with all due respect, he's not the strongest short simply because he basis his decisions on technicals rather than fundamentals (with a directional bias toward the market heading lower). Moves like the past month are designing to take out all those who do not have deep conviction that (I think anyway) can only be maintained from hard hitting fundamental economic analysis. We'll see. I say this is a ponzi that will experience a very significant cash crunch (gift card redemptions accelerating in a softening economy, lower average order size killing the true profit driver and the negative working capital model reversing an requiring cash). Smart funds will see it coming get out and go short so when Amazon has to raise more capital (debt won't be so easily available given that its debt to book is already at industry norms and it has all sorts of hidden leverage). Enron of the 2010's, but this time the corruption has largely been outside the corporation...

Message.Title: Detroit declared bankruptcy today - 20 billion in debt
Message.Msg: Bear sternz: By November, 2006, the company had total capital of approximately $66.7 billion $28 billion in 'level 3' assets on its books at the end of fiscal 2007 versus a net equity position of only $11.1 billion. This $11.1 billion supported $395 billion in assets,[7] which means a leverage ratio of 35.5 to 1. This highly leveraged balance sheet, consisting of many illiquid and potentially worthless assets, led to the rapid diminution of investor and lender confidence, which finally evaporated as Bear was forced to call the New York Federal Reserve to stave off the looming cascade of counterparty risk which would ensue from forced liquidation. Lehman bros Lehman Brothers filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on September 15, 2008. According to Bloomberg, reports filed with the U.S. Bankruptcy Court, Southern District of New York (Manhattan) on September 16 indicated that JPMorgan Chase & Co. provided Lehman Brothers with a total of $138 billion in "Federal Reserve-backed advances." The cash-advances by JPMorgan Chase were repaid by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York for $87 billion on September 15 and $51 billion on September 16.[18]
